Division.LongName: Div Of Chem, Bioeng, Env, & Transp Sys

Award.AbstractNarration:
1415190
Reinhart

Municipal solid waste generation continues to grow globally. Today it is estimated that 3 billion urban residents generate 1.2 kg per person per day (1.3 billion tonnes per year. By 2025 that figure is likely to reach 4.3 billion urban residents generating about 1.42 kg/capita/day (3.1 lb/cap/day) of municipal solid waste (2.2 billion tonnes per year). The majority of the waste generated in the US is landfilled (~53.6 %); and over 40 % of the world?s MSW is landfilled.

This symposium is the annual meeting of the US and international experts in the area of solid waste management. These are critical meetings as the participant share their most recent findings in landfill operations, new research areas and future issue which may arise.

Another important aspect of Symposium such as this one is that it provides a forum for young faculty and students to participate and gain knowledge from those in the field. NSF funds would be used to provide deeply discounted registration fees for graduate students and attendees from developing countries. Therefore the discussions and findings of the symposium will provide training for next generation workers, primarily in environmental engineering and will deepen understanding of this area for countries that may entirely depend on landfills for waste management. The outcomes of the symposium include a webpage with a summary of all sessions and a published book of abstracts. Frequently, review papers are also a product of the symposium. The attendees represent many countries and are typically gender diverse. For example, the planning group is 50% female, includes one Hispanic male, and is composed of senior and junior faculty and a student.

Institution.Name: The University of Central Florida Board of Trustees
Institution.ORG_LGL_BUS_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF CENTRAL FLORIDA BOARD OF TRUSTEES, THE

POR.DRECONTENT:
Municipal Solid Waste (MSW) generation rates continue to grow globally.  The majority of the waste generated in the US is landfilled and over 40% of the world's MSW is landfilled.  While significant efforts are made to divert wastes from landfills, this practice will continue long into the future.  Of the tens of thousands of existing landfills, major challenges remain regarding control of fugitive gaseous and liquid emissions.  The 8th InterContinental Landfill Symposium (ICLRS) was focused on meeting these challenges in creative and innovative ways.  It brought together world experts in the field to share research ideas, experimental protocol, and thoughts on policy.  The symposium offered innovative and transformative landfill research ideas from all over the world and promoted new and continued collaborations.  the symposium was organized into 21 sessions that addressed all aspects of landfill reserach.  During each session, the emphasis was on crticial discussions and detailed exploration of an important contemporary topic.

Ensuring safe and economical operation of MSW landfills benefits society from the perspectives of environmental improvement, economic waste management, and energy generation.  The 8th ICLRS was attended by 100 individuals representing 18 countries and including 19 students.  Attendees were from industry, consulting, academics, and govenmental organizations.  The discussions and findings of the symposium provided training for next generation workers, primarily in environmental engineering, and deepened understanding in this area for countries that may entirely depend on landiflls for waste management.  The products of the symposium included a webppage, a published book of abstracts, and a special edition of the Journal of Waste Management (April 2016).


Last Modified: 01/08/2016
Modified by: Debra R Reinhart
POR.POR_COPY_TXT: Municipal Solid Waste (MSW) generation rates continue to grow globally. The majority of the waste generated in the US is landfilled and over 40% of the world's MSW is landfilled. While significant efforts are made to divert wastes from landfills, this practice will continue long into the future. Of the tens of thousands of existing landfills, major challenges remain regarding control of fugitive gaseous and liquid emissions. The 8th InterContinental Landfill Symposium (ICLRS) was focused on meeting these challenges in creative and innovative ways. It brought together world experts in the field to share research ideas, experimental protocol, and thoughts on policy. The symposium offered innovative and transformative landfill research ideas from all over the world and promoted new and continued collaborations. the symposium was organized into 21 sessions that addressed all aspects of landfill reserach. During each session, the emphasis was on crticial discussions and detailed exploration of an important contemporary topic. Ensuring safe and economical operation of MSW landfills benefits society from the perspectives of environmental improvement, economic waste management, and energy generation. The 8th ICLRS was attended by 100 individuals representing 18 countries and including 19 students. Attendees were from industry, consulting, academics, and govenmental organizations. The discussions and findings of the symposium provided training for next generation workers, primarily in environmental engineering, and deepened understanding in this area for countries that may entirely depend on landiflls for waste management. The products of the symposium included a webppage, a published book of abstracts, and a special edition of the Journal of Waste Management (April 2016).
